Realizing A(1) equivariantly

Jun 11, 2019

One of the motivations for this post was to try to see if the spectrum (or rather, any of the spectra) whose cohomology is as a Steenrod module can be constructed in the -equivariant setting. Our group in this post will always be . To explain the question in the equivariant setting, we need to recall a few things. Recall that denotes the one-point compactification of the inclusion of the fixed point of the sign representation of , and that is the generator of . The mod cohomology of a point is then , where .

There are Steenrod operations, , where has degree and has degree . Moreover, acts trivially on and , and acts by on . Now, one can define a subalgebra of the -equivariant Steenrod algebra as the subalgebra generated by and . It is not hard to list out a basis:

The equivariant dual Steenrod algebra is

where , lives in degree , and lives in degree .

I originally wanted to construct a -spectrum whose -cohomology is as a module over the -equivariant Steenrod algebra. (The extension of the action of on itself to the entire -equivariant Steenrod can be done in the same way as in the nonequivariant setting.) This, however, is not the right question to be asking.

To understand this philosophy, consider the Moore spectrum . It is pretty obviously realizable -equivariantly, but this realization is rather boring. The more interesting “realization” of arises from viewing it as the geometric fixed points of a -spectrum, namely , where is the -equivariant Hopf map. This map satisfies the property that its underlying map is , while upon taking geometric fixed points, it is just multiplication by . (Recall that the geometric fixed points is .) One should think of as a “double” of .

This particular story works even with the spectrum . Classically (at the prime ), it is the Thom spectrum of a complex bundle over ; this space has a -action (by complex conjugation), which induces a -action on ; call this -spectrum . The space is just as a -space. Since is the Thom spectrum of the -equivariant map (trivial action on the target) extending the map from detecting , we find that is the Thom spectrum of the nonequivariant map detecting . In other words, the geometric fixed points is equal to the -quotient .

From this perspective, a natural question to ask if we’re trying to “realize” (in the loosest possible sense) a finite spectrum as a -spectrum is if it admits a “doubling” (whatever that means). Then, this doubled spectrum might be the underlying spectrum of a -spectrum, and our original spectrum might be the fixed points. What does doubling mean? One definition might be that is the double of if the relations defined by the Steenrod action on agree with the relations defined by the action of the subalgebra generated by for on . We’ll give a better definition later. Note that not every spectrum can just be doubled: the (underlying spectrum of the) double of is , the double of is , but the double of does not exist (thanks to Hopf invariant one).

It so happens that in the case of , doubling is indeed legal, at least non-equivariantly. Indeed, there is a spectrum , whose cohomology is free over the subalgebra of generated by and . What we’d like, therefore, is to construct a -spectrum whose underlying is , and whose geometric fixed points is .

To construct , we notice that splits off of the smash product of the doubled question mark and its Spanier-Whitehead dual: . We should therefore attempt to lift the doubled question mark complex to the -equivariant setting. There is a map , and its composite with is null. Therefore, one gets a map . The Thom spectrum of this map is our replacement for the dual of the question mark complex . Then splits off ; the composite of the coevaluation and evaluation maps is the Euler characteristic of , which is — an equivalence -locally.

We finally define to be the cofiber of the coevaluation map . By construction, the fixed points and underlying desiderata hold true. I think, but haven’t checked, that its cohomology is free over the subalgebra generated by and of the quotient of the -equivariant Steenrod algebra by the two sided ideal generated by .

What’s the point? Recall (Lin’s theorem) that there is a -adic equivalence , so there is a spectral sequence that runs

Any element of is represented by a coset of elements in the -page, and this coset is called the root invariant of . An alternative description is as follows: there is a minimal such that the map , and is the coset of lifts of to the fiber of the map . One can calculate that , , .

The root invariant doesn’t preserve multiplicative relations in any reasonable manner (e.g., isn’t zero), so if is a spectrum, there isn’t necessarily another spectrum with the same number of cells such that all primary attaching maps for are contained in the root invariant of the corresponding attaching maps for . This should be thought of as the double of , and our philosophy on doubles shows that we should really ask that be a -spectrum with as its geometric fixed points. (One way to make the relationship between geometric fixed points and the root invariant precise is by the following observation. Let be the geometric fixed points homomorphism. Then the root invariant of is equal to the collection of elements in the Mahowald invariant with highest -degree.) What we’ve shown in this post is that such a exists for . Moreover, the style of proof suggests that the resolution of this question for a spectrum depends very heavily on the specific spectrum, and that proving a general such “doublability”/”deroot-ifying” result is probably not possible.

I want to conclude this post with a cute potential application of the construction of . Define a genuine -spectrum as follows. We use the equivalence of genuine -spectra with the data of triples of naive -spectra , non-equivariant spectra (playing the role of geometric fixed points), and a map to the Tate construction of . Then has underlying naive -spectrum as with the trivial -action, geometric fixed points , and as the inclusion of the non-negatively indexed summands.

The spectrum is the height analogue of the -spectrum . We know that there is an equivalence , so it is natural to ask if there is an equivalence . We can obtain a map from the left hand side to the right hand side: it is given by using the multiplication on and the maps (obvious) and , where the final map uses the universal property of and the Real orientability of . Now, this map is an equivalence on underlying. Moreover, upon taking geometric fixed points, we obtain a map

which is an equivalence since . This doesn’t fully prove that the map is an equivalence, though: we need to show that it is an equivalence of naive/Borel -spectra.

We can instead regard the above discussion as providing evidence for our desired equivalence. A better proof would utilize the fact, which I learnt from Mark Behrens, that the equivariant homology of has been computed: it is , where

(I think there’s a typo in Definition 6.5, which writes down the profile function for this subalgebra.) For instance, , and

I believe, but haven’t checked, that the homology of is , where

Since we have an equivariant map , to show that it’s an equivalence we only need to prove the same is true on mod homology. The induced map on homology goes . In other words, we need to show that . This is a consequence of the claim that its cohomology is free over the subalgebra generated by and of the quotient of the -equivariant Steenrod algebra by the two sided ideal generated by .
